ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Blood cell development; drawing shows the steps a blood stem cell goes through to become a red blood cell, platelet, or white blood cell. Drawing shows a myeloid stem cell becoming a red blood cell, platelet, or myeloblast, which then becomes a white blood cell. Drawing also shows a lymphoid stem cell becoming a lymphoblast and then one of several different types of white blood cells.

Captions.MediaCaption: Blood cell development. A blood stem cell goes through several steps to become a red blood cell, platelet, or white blood cell.

MediaContent.Comment: The following sentence will be added as the last sentence when making the media link in each summary because it will vary depending on the type of cancer: "(type of cancer) is cancer of the (type of cell)." Example: "Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is cancer of the myeloblasts."

ProposedUse.Summary: Childhood Acute Myeloid Leukemia/Other Myeloid Malignancies Treatment

ProcessingStatus.ProcessingStatusValue: Approved by expert reviewer with changes
ProcessingStatus.Comment: Recommended the following: Change labels from Pre-myeloid cell and Pre-lymphoid cell to Myeloid stem cell and Lymphoid stem cell, respectively. Move the Myeloblast cell and label to the right and draw arrows from the Myeloid stem cell to the Myeloblast and then to the Granulocytes (on the Expanded tree) and the neutrophil (unlabelled;on the Basic Tree). (Bascially, the only cell types that come from the myeloblast are the granulocytes.) Draw longer arrows directly from the Myeloid stem cell to the Red blood cells and the Platelets.
2007-04-26 fourth draft; mm 2007-04-06 third draft; mm 2007-03-16 second draft; mm
